title: How to Make a Paper Clock

steps.title: Gather your supplies:
steps.content: Gather your supplies: Because this clock is made out of paper, it won't be able to move its hands on its own. You can move the hands yourself, but for that, you will need a brad or paper fastener. Here's a list of what you will need: [1] X Research source Paper plate Paper Brad (paper fastener) Scissors Crayons, markers, stickers, etc

steps.title: Find a plain, white paper plate.
steps.content: Find a plain, white paper plate. A plate with pictures on it may look pretty, but you won't be able to see the numbers. Don't worry, you can color the plate later. [2] X Research source If you can't find a plain paper plate, use a regular plate to trace a circle onto a piece of paper. Cut the circle out and use it instead.

steps.title: Write the numbers 1 to 12 around the rim of the plate.
steps.content: Write the numbers 1 to 12 around the rim of the plate. If you have a very narrow rim, then write the numbers on the plate itself. [3] X Research source Try to make the spaces between the numbers as even as you can. It might also be a good idea to write the numbers with a pencil first. You can draw over the numbers with crayon or marker later. Try to write the 12, 3, 6, and 9 first. This may help you keep things even. You can also use foam or sticker numbers instead of writing them out.

steps.title: Draw a two arrows on a piece of colored paper and cut them out.
steps.content: Draw a two arrows on a piece of colored paper and cut them out. One arrow should be a little shower than the other one. Make sure that the bigger arrow can reach the numbers. [4] X Research source The big arrow will be the minute hand, and the small hand will be the hour hand.

steps.title: Decorate the plate and arrows.
steps.content: Decorate the plate and arrows. If you want to add color to your clock, now is the time. You can color the clock with crayons, paint, or markers. [5] X Research source You can add stickers or even glitter to it. Try not to put too much on it, or you will not see the numbers. If you used paint or glitter glue, you will need to let everything dry before moving on.

steps.title: Poke a hole in the center of the clock.
steps.content: Poke a hole in the center of the clock. You can use a ballpoint pen, a toothpick, or a wooden skewer to do this. If you are a child, ask an adult to help you with this step. To find the center, flip the plate over so the back is facing you. Draw a huge X across the back of the clock. Make sure that the points of the X are touching the edges of the clock. The center of the X is the center of the clock.

steps.title: Punch a hole in the bottom of each arrow.
steps.content: Punch a hole in the bottom of each arrow. Line up the bottom of the arrows up first, then punch the hole through both arrows at the same time. This will make it more even. You can use a hole puncher to make this easier. If you don't have a hole punch, you can poke the hole using a ballpoint pen.

steps.title: Place the arrows on the clock.
steps.content: Place the arrows on the clock. Make sure that the hole in each arrow lines up with the hole in the clock. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Stick the brad through the holes.
steps.content: Stick the brad through the holes. The pointy end should be coming out of the back of the clock. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the cock over and flatten the prongs.
steps.content: Turn the cock over and flatten the prongs. Separate the prongs first, then flatten them against the plate. You can use a butter knife to pull the prongs apart. If you are a child, ask an adult to help you. Brads can be very sharp.

steps.title: Use your clock.
steps.content: Use your clock. Turn the clock back over so that you can see the numbers again. You can now move the arrows around. Try not to pull or tug too hard, or the paper will rip.

steps.title: Hot glue a piece of ribbon to the back of the clock so you can hang it.
steps.content: Hot glue a piece of ribbon to the back of the clock so you can hang it. Take a few inches of ribbon and fold it in half to make a loop. Tie the two ends into a knot to keep them together. Turn the clock over so that you can see the back. Put a drop of hot glue close to the top. Press the ribbon down onto it and let it dry. Glue guns can get very hot. Ask an adult to help you with this step. You can also staple the ribbon to the plate instead.

steps.title: Add a swinging pendulum to your clock.
steps.content: Add a swinging pendulum to your clock. Cut a long, skinny rectangle out of some yellow paper. Cut a circle out of the same paper and glue it to the bottom of the rectangle. Wait for the glue to dry, then poke a hole near the top of the rectangle. Turn the clock over so that the back is facing you, and open up the brad. Slip the prongs through the hole in the rectangle, then flatten them again. Turn your clock back over and swing the pendulum.

steps.title: Glue the clock onto a large sheet of brown paper.
steps.content: Glue the clock onto a large sheet of brown paper. Be careful not to get any glue onto the brad, or you may not be able to turn the arrows anymore. Cut a wave-like shape around the edges of the brown paper, and pin it to your wall. Your clock will look like a grandfather clock! Consider combining this with the swinging pendulum.

steps.title: Paint the clock face before you write the numbers down.
steps.content: Paint the clock face before you write the numbers down. If you want the paint the clock after you have written the numbers, you may need to re-write them. Some paint is translucent, and some paint is opaque.

steps.title: Outline the clock and arrows with some glitter glue.
steps.content: Outline the clock and arrows with some glitter glue. If you cannot find any glitter glue, then draw on the clock with some regular glue, and cover it with glitter. Tap the excess glitter off onto a sheet of paper. Use the paper to funnel the glitter back into its container.

steps.title: Label the two clock hands, or make them different colors.
steps.content: Label the two clock hands, or make them different colors. You can write "hour" on the little hand, and "minutes" on the big hand. You can also cut the hands out of two different colors, to make them easier to tell apart.

steps.title: Paint the rim of the paper plate a different color.
steps.content: Paint the rim of the paper plate a different color. This will make your clock look even more realistic. Colors such as black, brown, blue, or red will work great for this. You can also try using gold or silver paint.

steps.title: Decorate the numbers.
steps.content: Decorate the numbers. You don't have to write the numbers using marker. Try using stickers or foam letters instead. [8] X Research source You can also try using a silver or gold permanent marker. Consider using the Roman numbers instead: I, II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI, and XII. Start at the 1 o'clock position with the "I" and continue around the rim. The XII should be at the top of the clock, where the 12 would be.
